Method Detail

newInstance

java.lang.Object newInstance(java.lang.String arg)
                             throws CacheException
Creates a new instance of this class by calling %New() method on the server. This method is similar to constructor of the class.

Parameters:
arg - Argument that is passed to %New() method.
Returns:
a newly created instance.
Throws:
CacheException

newInstance

java.lang.Object newInstance(com.intersys.cache.CacheObject cobj)
                             throws CacheException
This method should not be called by application code. it is only used internally by Java Binding Engine. It creates a new instance of the Java class in JVM memory corresponding to an already existing instance on the server that already has proxy in JVM.

Parameters:
cobj - A proxy object in JVM corresponding to a server side object.
Returns:
A new Java instance of the object.
Throws:
CacheException

newInstance

java.lang.Object newInstance(com.intersys.cache.CacheObject cobj,
                             boolean dynamic)
                             throws CacheException
This method should not be called by application code. it is only used internally by Java Binding Engine. It creates a new instance of the Java class in JVM memory corresponding to an already existing instance on the server that already has proxy in JVM. If argument dynamic is true then the new instance is supposed to live in Dynamic Java Binding client. If a projection class can not be loaded into JVM memory the Java class for a new object will be RegisteredObject. It still will be able to access all properties of the correct class. If dynamic is false the new instance is assumed to live in static Java Binding Client and thus the correct projection class is required.

Parameters:
cobj - A proxy object in JVM corresponding to a server side object.
dynamic - whether an instance is used by dynamic Java Binding.
Returns:
A new Java instance of the object.
Throws:
CacheException

java.lang.Object createClientObject()
                                    throws CacheException
Throws:
CacheException

openObject

java.lang.Object openObject(Id id)
                            throws CacheException
Opens an instance of a class given its Id. Runs %OpenId method on the server.

Parameters:
id - Id of the object
Returns:
a newly opened object.
Throws:
CacheException

openObject

java.lang.Object openObject(Oid oid)
                            throws CacheException
Opens an instance of a class given its Object identity. Runs %Open method on the server. Oid should never be costructed by application code. It is an opaque object used by Cache and can only be returned by getOid() method.

Parameters:
oid - Oid of the object
Returns:
a newly opened object.
Throws:
CacheException
See Also:
Persistent.getOid()

deleteObject

void deleteObject(Id id)
                  throws CacheException
Throws:
CacheException

createKey

CandidateKey createKey(java.lang.String keyName)
                       throws CacheException
Creates an empty CandidateKey object for this class. A key with SQL name keyName must be defined in the class. It is ususally defined as unique index on the corresponding table.

Subsequently set methods can be used to set values for primary key.

Parameters:
keyName - The name of the key (Unique Index) as defined in its SQL definition.
Returns:
Key represented as an empty CandidateKey object for this class or null if there is no primary key.
Throws:
CacheException - If the key with given name is not defined.
See Also:
createPrimaryKey()

createKey

CandidateKey createKey(java.lang.String keyName,
                       java.lang.String value)
                       throws CacheException
Creates a CandidateKey object for this class and sets its value according to the argument specified. If key definition refers to a single column then the value is just a string value for this column. If key definition refers to several columns then a list of comma separated values is expected as value argument.

A key with SQL name keyName must be defined in the class. It is ususally defined as unique index on the corresponding table.

The result of this method is the same as the result of 2 consequent statements:


CandidateKey key = cacheClass.createKey(keyName);
key.set(value);

Subsequently set methods can be used to modify values for the key.

Parameters:
value - Comma separated list of values for Primary Key columns.
keyName - The name of the key (Unique Index) as defined in its SQL definition.
Returns:
Key represented as an empty CandidateKey object for this class or null if there is no primary key.
Throws:
CacheException - If the key with given name is not defined.
See Also:
createPrimaryKey()

createBestCandidateKey

CandidateKey createBestCandidateKey()
                                    throws CacheException
Creates an empty CandidateKey object for this class. If primary key is designated for the class then it retruns primary key. Otherwise it retruns one of candidate keys. If there are no candidate keys available returns null.

Subsequently set methods can be used to set values for primary key.

Returns:
Primary key represented as an empty CandidateKey object for this class or null if there is no primary key.
Throws:
CacheException
See Also:
createPrimaryKey()

createPrimaryKey

CandidateKey createPrimaryKey()
                              throws CacheException
Creates an empty CandidateKey object for this class that corresponds to primary key. If no primary key is designated for the class returns null.

Subsequently set methods can be used to set values for primary key.

Returns:
Primary key represented as an empty CandidateKey object for this class or null if there is no primary key.
Throws:
CacheException
See Also:
createBestCandidateKey()

createPrimaryKey

CandidateKey createPrimaryKey(java.lang.String value)
                              throws CacheException
Creates CandidateKey object for this class and sets its value according to the argument specified. If Primary Key refers to a single column then the value is just a string value for this column. If primary key refers to several columns then a list of comma separated values is expected as value argument.

The result of this method is the same as the result of 2 consequent statements:


CandidateKey key = cacheClass.createPrimaryKey();
key.set(value);

Subsequently set methods can be used to modify values for the key.

Parameters:
value - Comma separated list of values for Primary Key columns.
Returns:
Primary key represented as CandidateKey object for this class or null if there is no primary key.
Throws:
CacheException
See Also:
createBestCandidateKey()

openByKey

java.lang.Object openByKey(CandidateKey key)
                           throws CacheException
Opens an instance of a class given its primary or candidate key.

Parameters:
key - CandidateKey represented as CandidateKey object.
Returns:
a newly opened object.
Throws:
CacheException - if opened failed or there is no object with given primary key.

openByPrimaryKey

java.lang.Object openByPrimaryKey(java.lang.String key)
                                  throws CacheException
Opens an instance of a class given string value of its primary key. If the key refers to a single column then the value is just a string value for this column. If the key refers to several columns then a list of comma separated values is expected as value argument. The result of this method is the same as the result of the following statements:


CandidateKey key = cacheClass.createPrimaryKey();
key.set(value);
Object opened = cacheClass.openByKey(key);

Parameters:
key - String value of the key.
Returns:
a newly opened object.
Throws:
CacheException - if opened failed or there is no object with given primary key.

                                 throws CacheException

isVerified

boolean isVerified()
Checks whether the class has been verified to have a valid and consistent Java projection and whether the projection is up to date.

Returns:
true if the class has been verified.

verifyClass

void verifyClass()
                 throws CacheException
Verifies the class to have a valid and consistent Java projection and whether the projection is up to date.

Throws:
CacheException

close

void close()
Releases the CacheClass object from JVM memory.
